articles.title: CDC reports first cruise norovirus outbreak this year, as nearly 90 people are infected

neutral.headline: Unfortunate Outbreak on Rotterdam Cruise Ship
neutral.body:
An outbreak of norovirus affected nearly 90 passengers and crew members on Holland America's Rotterdam cruise ship during a voyage from December 28 to January 9, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
The norovirus, a common gastrointestinal illness, led to symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhea among those affected on the cruise ship. The cruise line took immediate action in response to the outbreak, implementing sanitation protocols and providing medical care to those who fell ill.
Instances of illnesses on cruise ships are not uncommon due to the close quarters and shared facilities on board, making it easier for viruses to spread. Holland America's Rotterdam cruise ship has since taken measures to prevent further cases of norovirus, including thorough cleaning and disinfection of the ship's common areas.
While outbreaks of norovirus can be concerning, it is important to note that the cruise industry adheres to strict health and safety protocols to ensure the well-being of passengers and crew members. Monitoring and addressing instances of illness on board are standard procedures to mitigate the spread of viruses and provide necessary care to those affected.
